text: To the chief Musician upon Shushaneduth, Michtam of David, to teach; when he strove with Aramnaharaim  and with Aramzobah, when Joab returned, and smote of Edom in the valley of salt twelve  thousand. O God, thou hast cast us off, thou hast scattered us, thou hast been displeased; O turn thyself to us again.

text_niv: Psalm 60For the director of music. To the tune of “The Lily of the Covenant.” A miktam of David. For teaching. When he fought Aram Naharaim and Aram Zobah, and when Joab returned and struck down twelve thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.You have rejected us, O God, and burst forth upon us;you have been angry—now restore us!
text_esv: O God, you have rejected us, broken our defenses; you have been angry; oh, restore us.
text_nlt: You have rejected us, O God, and broken our defenses.You have been angry with us; now restore us to your favor.
text_msg: A David psalm, when he fought against Aram-naharaim and Aram-zobah and Joab killed twelve thousand Edomites at the Valley of Salt.God! you walked off and left us,kicked our defenses to bitsAnd stalked off angry.Come back. Oh please, come back!
text_nasb: For the choir director; according to Shushan Eduth. A Mikhtam of David, to teach; when he struggled with Aram-naharaim and with Aram-zobah, and Joab returned, and smote twelve thousand of Edom in the Valley of Salt. O God, You have rejected us. You have broken us; You have been angry; O, restore us.
context: Psalm 60's superscription provides crucial historical context. 'To the chief Musician upon Shushaneduth' likely indicates a melody or instrument ('Shushaneduth' probably referring to 'lilies of testimony'). 'Michtam of David, to teach' suggests a psalm of profound reflection intended for instruction. The psalm recounts a time when David's kingdom faced multiple military threats. 'Aramnaharaim' (Aram of the Two Rivers) and 'Aramzobah' were powerful Aramean kingdoms north and northeast of Israel. David's conflict with these kingdoms is documented in 2 Samuel 8:3-8 and 1 Chronicles 18:3-8, detailing his victories. However, the psalm suggests initial setbacks or the perceived threat before the ultimate triumph. The reference to Joab's victory over Edom 'in the valley of salt' (2 Samuel 8:13; 1 Chronicles 18:12) is especially poignant. While Joab achieved a decisive victory, slaying twelve thousand Edomites, the psalm emphasizes a sense of divine abandonment *before* this victory. The 'valley of salt' was likely south of the Dead Sea, a harsh and desolate region adding to the sense of hardship. The psalm’s composition likely followed an initial military setback against Aram, before Joab’s success in Edom turned the tide. Understanding this sequence is vital for interpreting the psalm's emotional arc from lament to eventual hope.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 60:1 captures the raw emotion of perceived divine abandonment during national crisis. 'O God, thou hast cast us off, thou hast scattered us, thou hast been displeased' expresses a deep sense of being rejected by God, which is intensified by the historical context of military struggles. The phrase 'cast us off' speaks to a broken covenant relationship, a feeling that God has withdrawn his protection and favor. 'Scattered us' evokes the image of a defeated army, routed and dispersed, losing its strength and coherence. 'Thou hast been displeased' suggests a sense of national guilt or disobedience, a recognition that Israel's sins might have provoked God's anger. This recognition of divine displeasure is a critical component of repentance and seeking restoration. The phrase 'O turn thyself to us again' is a plea for divine favor to be restored. It implies that God has the power to change his posture towards his people. It acknowledges God's sovereignty and mercy, suggesting that even in moments of perceived rejection, hope remains. This verse embodies a crucial theological tension: the experience of God's seeming absence alongside a persistent faith in His ability to restore and heal. It is a testament to the enduring belief in God's covenant faithfulness, even when circumstances seem to contradict it.
application: Psalm 60:1 offers several powerful applications for contemporary Christians. First, it validates the expression of lament and disappointment to God. When facing personal or collective crises – job loss, relationship breakdown, illness, or social injustice – it's acceptable and even encouraged to honestly express feelings of abandonment and displeasure to God. Suppressing these emotions can be spiritually damaging. Second, the verse underscores the importance of self-reflection and repentance during difficult times. Instead of solely blaming external factors, Christians should consider whether their actions or attitudes have contributed to the challenging circumstances. This requires honest introspection and a willingness to confess sins. Third, it reminds us that perceived divine abandonment doesn't necessarily equate to actual abandonment. Like David, we may experience times when God feels distant or unresponsive, but this doesn't negate His covenant faithfulness. Fourth, it encourages persistent prayer and seeking God's face. Even when feeling cast off, we should continue to plead with God to 'turn himself to us again'. This demonstrates unwavering faith and reliance on His mercy. Fifth, Psalm 60:1 calls for empathy towards others experiencing hardship. We should avoid simplistic explanations for their suffering and instead offer support, prayer, and practical assistance. Finally, the historical context of the psalm reminds us that setbacks can precede eventual victory. Just as Joab's victory followed initial setbacks, our struggles may ultimately lead to breakthroughs and a deeper understanding of God's grace. Therefore, hold onto hope, even amidst despair, trusting that God is working even when we cannot see it.
prayer: Sovereign God, I come before you with a heart that often echoes the Psalmist’s cry: ‘O God, thou hast cast us off!’ There are times when I feel distant from you, when your presence seems veiled, and your favor withdrawn. Forgive me for the moments I doubt your love and faithfulness. I confess that I sometimes contribute to my own hardships through choices and actions. Search my heart, reveal any hidden sins, and lead me to repentance. I long for your presence, Lord. Turn yourself to me again. Restore my joy, renew my strength, and revive my spirit. Help me to trust in your unfailing love even when circumstances seem bleak. Grant me the grace to persevere in prayer and to seek your face relentlessly. And Lord, as I navigate these challenges, help me to be a source of comfort and support to others who are also experiencing the sting of apparent abandonment. May your love shine through me, bringing hope and healing to a hurting world. In Jesus’ name, Amen.
